oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A seven-page narrative of the early life of Thomas Green Ryman as written by his daughter, Daisy Ryman Coggins. The narrative discusses how Ryman grew up and developed an interest in river commerce.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Daisy Ryman Coggins
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. Restored in 1994; placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A three-page narrative describing the 1869 wedding of Thomas Green Ryman to Mary Elizabeth Baugh. The narrative describes the wedding ceremony and the dresses worn by party-goers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mrs. John A. Roundtree
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. Restored in 1994; placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A three-page narrative providing a brief history of Nashville and Tennessee. It describes the social pastimes of Tennesseans in the 18th and 19th centuries. "Chapter 1" is written in the upper left corner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Daisy Ryman Coggins
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Papa's First Boat -- Steamer 'Alpha,'" by Leslie Ryman Barton
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A three-page narrative describing how Thomas Green Ryman bought his first boat with $3,000 sewn into the lining of his coat. The story describes the number of times the steamer "Alpha" ran aground or sank, claiming the boat sank 13 times, always on the 13th of the month. Also described is the first boat Ryman had built, the "Eddyville", in 1872. The narrative tells the fate of the "Alpha," including its decommissioning, and the sale prices of the vessel's parts.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Daisy Ryman Coggins
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. Restored in 1994; placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music -- Tennessee -- Nashville; Country musicians; Theaters -- Tennessee -- Nashville -- History; Nashville (Tenn.) -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of two unidentified men with guitars performing on stage. A barn faade is in the background with a partially visible "WSM Grand Ole Opry" sign over the doors. Several men are also visible. One appears to be playing a piano and two more are in the background but not part of the performance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Grand Ole Opry is a radio variety show featuring country music entertainers performing before a live audience. The program began in October 1925, sponsored by the Nashville-based National Life and Accident Insurance Company. The insurance company's motto was "We Shield Millions." The initials provided the call letters for WSM, the radio station that broadcasts the Opry.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Auditoriums; Stages (Platforms); Columns; Benches; Concert halls; Historic buildings; Tabernacles (Buildings)
Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Country gospel music; Music-halls; Historic American Buildings Survey
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior view of the stage and seats of the Ryman from the center aisle of the structure.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jack E. Boucher
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is one of a series of photographs taken of the Ryman Auditorium between 1970 and 1972 for the Historic American Buildings Survey. The pew seating was organized and numbered by rows, with each seat number being noted on the back of the pew. Pews were to hold 10 persons. This main-level seating was reserved and sold out months in advance. Gallery or balcony seating was first come, first-served.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ticket to the Hon. Roscoe Conklin Simmons speech
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Auditoriums; Concert halls; Historic buildings; Tabernacles (Buildings); Tickets
Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Tickets; Speeches, addresses, etc.; Simmons, Roscoe (Roscoe Conklin)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ticket for a speech given at the Ryman Auditorium by well-known African American orator, the Hon. Roscoe Conklin Simmons.

Roscoe Conklin [also Conkling] Simmons (1881-1951) was a nephew by marriage to Booker T. Washington. He wrote for the Chicago Defender and Chicago Tribune newspapers. Active in Republican Party politics, he was a delegate to the Pan-African Congress in Paris (1919), and seconded the renomination of Herbert Hoover at the party's national convention in 1932.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Broadside advertising an anti-women's suffrage event at the Ryman

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Women -- Suffrage; Broadsides
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside advertising a mass meeting at the Ryman to "Save the South" from the Susan B. Anthony amendment and federal suffrage force bills. It advertises that Oscar Underwood, Ruffin Pleasant, E. B. Stahlman, Charlotte Rowe, Frank Bond, and Gus Dyer will speak. Mrs. Thomas Malone Jr. will sing and Judge J. C. Higgins will preside.

The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Auditoriums; Historic buildings
Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Veterans; Confederate veteran (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A photograph of the "Nashville Tabernacle" in the May 1897, Volume V, Number 5, of the Confederate Veteran magazine. Text beneath the image states that the 7th reunion of the United Confederate Veterans is to be held there June 22-24, 1897. Text above comments on rates for advertising in the publication, and comments on the patrons for whom the Confederate Veteran is published.

The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. Restored in 1994; placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Auditoriums; Concert halls; Historic buildings; Tabernacles (Buildings); Architectural elements; Stone carving; Doors & doorways
Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Country gospel music; Music-halls
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Entrance on the east (4th Avenue) side of the Ryman Auditorium. Next to the entrance is a sign which reads: "WSM 'Grand Ole Opry' Tours Tickets On Sale At Box Office." Entrance is now covered by 2-story addition built in 1994. Photograph labeled "Architectural detail #2."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jack E. Boucher, Historic American Buildings Survey
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Sam Jones, the Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. When Ryman died in 1904, the building was named in his honor. From 1942-1974, the Ryman hosted the Grand Ole Opry broadcast. Vacant from 1974-1992, a series of Emmylou Harris concerts renewed sufficient interest in it that it was restored in 1994. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph shows the entertainers on a raised stage and the backs of the heads of the audience, seated in a semi-circle. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Audiences; Concerts; Events; Music; Singers; Clothing & dress; Guitars; Stages (Platforms); Stage props; Pews; Auditoriums; Concert halls; Historic buildings; Tabernacles (Buildings)
Acuff, Roy; Smoky Mountain Boys; Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Country gospel music; Music-halls
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo taken from the audience level of a performance at the Ryman by Roy Acuff and his Smoky Mountain Boys. Audience, stage, backstage, electronics, and advertisements are all in view.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: After broadcasting from a number of locations, the Grand Ole Opry moved to its 31-year home at the Ryman Auditorium on June 5, 1943. Roy Acuff's country music career took off in the 1930s as he sang and fiddled with his group, the Smoky Mountain Boys. Acuff joined the Opry in 1938. The month of September 1969 found him entertaining the troops in Vietnam, opening the first in his chain of Roy Acuff Cannonball Kitchen restaurants in Nashville, and performing at the Grand Ole Opry.

Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Country gospel music; Music-halls
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Exterior view of the Ryman Auditorium at 5th Avenue North. Pieces of the building's history are clearly visible in the signs and plaques that are affixed to the structure. In view are signs proclaiming "Grand Ole Opry House," "WSM Grand Ole Opry," and "The National Life and Accident Insurance Co."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: After broadcasting from a number of early locations, the Grand Ole Opry moved to its 31-year home at the Ryman Auditorium on June 5, 1943. The Opry broadcast from this location until 1974. The March 15, 1974 show was the last broadcast at the Ryman before the Opry moved to its new home at Opryland. The Ryman Auditorium was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Auditoriums; Concert Halls; Historic buildings; Tabernacles (Buildings); Balconies; Columns; Benches

Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music -- Tennessee -- Nashville; Country gospel music; Music-halls; Historic American Buildings Survey; Confederate States of America. Army -- Anniversaries, etc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior of the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, Tennessee, showing the main-level pews and the Confederate Gallery taken from the stage area.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jack E. Boucher
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sam Jones raised the money for a Tabernacle gallery to accommodate the 1897 Confederate Veterans Association Reunion. The three-day event in June 1897 (coinciding with the Tennessee Centennial Exposition) brought almost 100,000 people to Nashville. In honor of the legacy and donations brought about by the convention, the gallery was named "The Confederate Gallery."

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Houses; Fences
Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904; Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The house of Tom Ryman who personally designed much of the structure. Two-story wood frame Victorian with large wrap-around veranda, square tower on left, and second floor gazebo/porch; ornate iron fence around property. This is the earlier of two photographs in one folder. The trees around the house have just been planted.
Thomas Ryman, a prominent Nashville businessman and riverboat captain, was responsible for the construction of the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was renamed in Ryman's honor after his death in 1904.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Auditoriums; Concert halls; Historic buildings; Tabernacles (Buildings); Architectural elements; Synagogues
Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Country gospel music; Music-halls; Congregation Sherith Israel (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, Tennessee. Small house at left later (1905) became the home of Congregation Sherith Israel, also known as the Fifth Avenue Synagogue. The photograph appears to have been taken in the winter as the trees are leafless.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert (Plate #305)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. Restored in 1994; placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Auditoriums; Historic buildings; Concert halls
Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Congregational churches -- sermons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ryman Auditorium interior, from Hardeman's Tabernacle Sermons, Volume 1, by N. B. Hardeman, image facing page 15. The full congregation can be seen in the balcony and the floor with several individuals on the railed stage in the center. The curtain is raised above the stage. Text beneath the image reads "Sunday afternoon, April 9, 1922."

The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. Restored in 1994; placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ryman Auditorium, exterior view, front, from southwest. Signs near building advertise Pizza +, the Drake Motel, Opry Tours (tickets inside), WSM Grand Ole Opry, and National Life and Accident Insurance. Also visible are the chimney of the Hermitage Laundry and part of a sign reading "Tennessee Gift Shop."

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Auditoriums; Passageways; Architecture; Historic buildings
Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Theaters -- Tennessee -- Nashville -- History; Nashville (Tenn.) -- History; Boucher, Jack E., 1931- ; Thompson, H. C.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior of the Ryman Auditorium shows the outer hallway with shapes of windows outlined by sunlight; wooden floor, large doors into auditorium.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jack E. Boucher
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Known as the Mother Church of Country Music, Nashvilles Ryman Auditorium, designed by architect H.C. Thompson, was originally built as a religious meeting hall and was called the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by steamboat captain Thomas Green Ryman, after his conversion at an 1885 revival preached by Sam Jones. The Ryman was the home of the Grand Ole Opry from 1943 to 1974.

Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Country gospel music; Music-halls
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of a stone carving on the front of the Ryman Auditorium reading "Union Gospel Tabernacle 1891" reflecting the building's original name. The carving is framed by a gothic-inspired faux-window frame.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jack E. Boucher
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. Restored in 1994; placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Music; Guitars; Audiences; Singers; Musicians; Concerts; Music halls

Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music -- Tennessee -- Nashville; Country musicians; Theaters -- Tennessee -- Nashville -- History; Nashville (Tenn.) -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph shows the entertainers on a raised stage and the backs of the heads of the audience, seated in a semi-circle. The facade of a barn is the background with a sign over the doors reading "WSM Grand Ole Opry." A small sign to the right of the doors reads, "A Service of National Life and Accident Co." Advertisements can be seen hanging in front of the barn. The stage is full of musicians and performers, none of whom are identified in the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Grand Ole Opry is a radio variety show featuring country music entertainers performing before a live audience. The program began in October 1925, sponsored by the Nashville-based National Life and Accident Insurance Company. The insurance company's motto was "We Shield Millions." The initials provided the call letters for WSM, the radio station that broadcasts the Opry.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Sam Jones, the Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. When Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. From 1942-1974, the Ryman hosted the Grand Ole Opry broadcast. Vacant from 1974-1992, a series of Emmylou Harris concerts renewed sufficient interest in it that it was restored in 1994. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The interior of the Ryman Auditorium showing the stage. Large oval signs on either side of the stage reads, "WSM Grand Ole Opry," as does a podium at stage left (house right). A stained-glass-inspired set piece is seen center stage near two pianos, one facing forward, the other backward.

Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Country gospel music; Music-halls; Historic American Buildings Survey

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jack E. Boucher
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is one of the series of photographs taken of the Ryman Auditorium between 1970 and 1972 for the Historic American Buildings Survey (HABS), a proposal put before the National Park Service during the Great Depression. This 1933 proposal called for documenting the historic architecture of America. HABS went on to become a permanent program of the National Park Service.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mary Elizabeth Baugh Ryman

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait photographs
Ryman, Mary Elizabeth Baugh, 1847-1920; Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904; Nashville (Tenn.); Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders portrait photograph of Mary Elizabeth Baugh Ryman (Mrs. Thomas G. Ryman Sr.).
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Giers & Koellein, Nashville photographers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary Elizabeth Baugh Ryman was born in Maury County to Wyatt Woodruff Baugh and Sarah Elizabeth Neely on January 3, 1847. After graduating from an Episcopal school in Franklin, she attended Franklin College near Nashville. Her roomate was Thomas Ryman's sister. Ryman courted Mary for over a year, and they married on February 3, 1869. She died in Atlanta on March 12, 1920, and was buried at Mount Olivet Cemetery in Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Auditoriums; Stages (Platforms); Concert halls; Historic buildings; Tabernacles (Buildings)
Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Country gospel music; Music-halls; Historic American Buildings Survey
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior view of the stage and seats of the Ryman taken from the extreme right of the structure.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jack E. Boucher
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image is part of a series of photographs taken of the Ryman Auditorium between 1970 and 1972 for the Historic American Buildings Survey. During this period, the Ryman Auditorium seated 3,300. Windows, including those appearing here, were opened for ventilation during the shows. Fans often watched and listened at these open windows, and some fans proved a challenge for Opry security (mostly off-duty firemen) by trying to climb in through the windows.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait photographs

Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904; Nashville (Tenn.); Union Gospel Tabernacle (Nashville, Tenn.); Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music; Country gospel music; Music-halls
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders photographic portrait of Thomas Green Ryman as a young man.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Giers & Koellein, Nashville photographers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Born in Nashville on October 12, 1841, Captain Tom Ryman had gathered a fleet of 35 riverboats by 1885 to form the Ryman Line. He proved to be the most influential man of his day in the Cumberland River shipping industry and fought railroad competition his entire life. The Rev. Sam Jones's revival in 1885 inspired Ryman to build the Union Gospel Tabernacle in Nashville--the structure that would carry his name as the famous Ryman Auditorium after his death in 1904.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Daisy and Pearl Ryman

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Hats; Dresses
Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904; Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of Daisy Ryman Coggins and Pearl Ryman Coggins, daughters of Thomas Green Ryman. Text on the back of the photograph states that Daisy's Ward Seminary diploma was made out to Marguerite Ryman, although she was always called "Daisy." The sisters married brothers named Coggins and moved to Georgia.

The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry; broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. Restored in 1994; placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Captain Thomas G. Ryman
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait photographs
Ryman, Thomas Green, -- 1841-1904; Nashville (Tenn.) -- Biography; Ryman, Thomas Green -- Portraits
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thomas Green Ryman, a riverboat captain and Nashville entrepreneur, built the Union Gospel Tabernacle between 1888 and 1892 at a cost of about $100,000. After Ryman's death in 1904, the Rev. Sam Jones proposed that the building's name; be changed to honor him. Afterwards, the building was known as the Ryman Auditorium. Captain Ryman was buried in Mt. Olivet Cemetery in Nashville, Tennessee, on Christmas Day 1904.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ryman females at Lookout Point
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Hats; Dresses; Cliffs; Mountains; Sightseers
Ryman, Mary Elizabeth Baugh, 1847-1920; Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904; Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Lookout Mountain (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image of several women posing on Lookout Point.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: S. S. Eaton & Co., Lookout Mountain
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Included in this photo of adventurous females are Mary Ryman (back row, third from left) and her daughter Daisy Ryman (front row, fifth from left). Mary was the wife of Thomas G. Ryman, Nashville riverboat captain and businessman; Daisy was one of his daughters. Daisy and her sister Pearl both married Coggins brothers and moved to Georgia. Mary later died in Atlanta (1920) and was brought back to Nashville for burial at Mt. Olivet Cemetery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Theodore Thomas Orchestra benefit at the Union Gospel Tabernacle
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Orchestras; Concerts; Auditoriums; Concert halls; Historic buildings; Tabernacles (Buildings)

Union Gospel Tabernacle (Nashville, Tenn.); Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Ryman, Thomas Green, 1841-1904; Thomas, Theodore, 1835-1905; Theodore Thomas Orchestra (Chicago, Ill.); Ladies' Hermitage Association; Hermitage (Hermitage, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior image of the Union Gospel Tabernacle including the audience and the Theodore Thomas Orchestra performing at a benefit staged by the Ladies' Hermitage Association to fund the preservation of The Hermitage, home of Andrew Jackson.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Giers & Koellein, Nashville photographers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The May Musical Festival of 1892 brought the Theodore Thomas Orchestra to Nashville to assist the Ladies' Hermitage Association in preservation efforts for The Hermitage. Founded in 1862, the orchestra toured extensively and then settled in Chicago. They would go on to become the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. This particular Nashville performance unfortunately lost money, operating at a deficit of $336.70.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Streetcar advertising temperance lecture at the Ryman
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Street railroads; Cable railroads; Streets; Grocery stores; Houses; Broadsides
Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Temperance; Cable cars (Streetcars); Baseball
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Streetcar on Buchanan Street; also shows J.A. Maxey Grocery. Rear of streetcar has broadsides for "Baseball Today" and "Hear Carmack on Temperance, Ryman Auditorium." Two children in hats stand outside the grocery. Several houses can be seen in the background. Photograph was used as a court exhibit in the D. C. Bain case.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: S. A. Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Ryman Auditorium opened in 1892 as the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by businessman Thomas Ryman for revivalist Samuel Porter Jones. After Ryman died in 1904, the building was renamed in his honor. Site of Grand Ole Opry broadcasts, 1942-1974, then vacant until a series of Emmylou Harris concerts (1992) renewed interest in it. Restored in 1994; placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1971 and National Historic Landmarks in 2001.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Auditoriums; Stages (Platforms); Benches; Theater curtains; Architecture; Historic buildings
Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Theaters -- Tennessee -- Nashville -- History; Nashville (Tenn.) -- History; Boucher, Jack E., 1931- ; Thompson, H. C.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior of the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, Tennessee, taken from the back right side of the balcony, showing stage and seats.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jack E. Boucher
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Known as the Mother Church of Country Music, Nashvilles Ryman Auditorium, designed by architect H. C. Thompson, was originally built as a religious meeting hall and was called the Union Gospel Tabernacle. It was built by steamboat captain Thomas Green Ryman, after his conversion at an 1885 revival preached by Sam Jones. The Ryman was the home of the Grand Ole Opry from 1943 to 1974.
